linkTarget.anchoringText: The "A" West heavy oil field is located on the Eastern Flank of the South Oman Salt Basin. The field was discovered in the seventies and was brought on stream in the eighties. The heavy oil is contained in two separate dome shaped unconformity traps (Fig. 1) that were formed by the deep erosive incision into a more than 800m thick sequence of high net-to-gross sandy braided river, aeolian and alluvial fan sandstones belonging to the Cambrian Haradh, Amin and Mahwis formations. This erosive palaeo-relief was subsequently sealed by an on-lapping infill of mudrock dominated deposits belonging to the Carboniferous - Permian Al Khlata and Gharif formations and Nahr Umr mudstones at the base of the overburden. Most of the "A" West STOIIP is contained in the braided river sandstones of the Haradh Formation. Porosity and permeability ranges from 23 - 27 % and 10 â€“ 5,000 mD, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Schematic Geological Cross Section of the "A" field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic Geological Cross Section of the "A" field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The most recent formation pressure data (Figure 2), collected in 2015 from the aquifer while drilling the 3.3 acre infill wells, appears to confirm the ability of the APO wells to lower the aquifer pressure below the development area quicker than expected. This new information triggered the need for the APO target revision. This revision was also deemed critical by the "N" field team, who were considering using the excess APO water from "A" field to support the "N" field water flooding project.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Positive Early Indications of Reservoir Response to the APO

formatted-caption.caption-text: Positive Early Indications of Reservoir Response to the APO

linkTarget.anchoringText: The "A" West, "N" and "K" West fields are adjacent fields roughly 10 km apart. The "A" West field produces from the Haradh, Amin and Mahwis formations see Figure 3. The "N" and "K" West fields mainly produce from the Mahwis formation. The RFT pressures collected in the aquifer below these fields all suggest a common aquifer pressure. The "N" field is developed as a bottom water flood, initially only with aquifer water. Since 2015 water is injected into the aquifer to maintain the reservoir pressure and improve the recovery factor. Also in "K" West water is injected to boost the recovery factor.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Cross-section through the "A" West and "N" field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross-section through the "A" West and "N" field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: An aquifer pressure below the thermal development area of ~6000 kPa (at 1105 m tvdss) is targeted, to meet the optimum steam flooding operating pressure in "A" West reservoir [ref.2]. In order to quickly meet a similar pressure target (Figure 4) and hence to achieve a more hydrostatic pressure gradient between reservoir and aquifer, 46000 m3/d aquifer offtake was recommended in the Field Development Plan (FDP). To deliver 46000 m3/d APO rate, 19 APO wells had been approved in the 2016 Business Plan. The 46000 m3/d APO capacity is only required until the targeted aquifer pressure is achieved, after which the APO rate will be reduced gradually to avoid oil cusping into the aquifer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Current and target Aquifer and Reservoir pressures

formatted-caption.caption-text: Current and target Aquifer and Reservoir pressures

linkTarget.anchoringText: The APO system is part of the "A" facilities comprising an APO inlet water tank, water treatment plant, steam generation units, surface pumps, well testing unit, gathering station, coolers and interconnecting flow lines and pipelines. A schematic outline of the facilities is shown in Figure 5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: "A" Field Facility Schematic

formatted-caption.caption-text: "A" Field Facility Schematic

linkTarget.anchoringText: The assumptions captured in this section, including wells and facilities uptime, are based on data collected in the past two years (Figure 6). The three curves in Figure 6 are:

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: APO wells average production performance

formatted-caption.caption-text: APO wells average production performance

linkTarget.anchoringText: The APO wells have been phased out to account for the planned steam ramp-up over the first three years. As of April 2016, 11 APO wells out of the planned 12 were up and running. AL-107 was suspended shortly after commissioning as a result of a complicated fish (ESP + cable). Four additional APO wells have been drilled in 2015, out of which two were commissioned in 2016 together with AL107. AL107 was restored early 2016. The three remaining APO wells were drilled in 2016 and commissioned in 2017/2018, together with the two remaining wells from the 2015 drilling campaign. The wells location and planned on-stream date are captured in Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: APO wells location and planned start-up timing

formatted-caption.caption-text: APO wells location and planned start-up timing

linkTarget.anchoringText: This section addresses the following three forecast questions (Figure 8):

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: APO Production Profile to Honor "A" West Operating Philosophy

formatted-caption.caption-text: APO Production Profile to Honor "A" West Operating Philosophy

linkTarget.anchoringText: The MBAL tool, part of the IPM suite, was employed to conduct the material balance analysis. A simple one water tank model was sufficient to populate the APO profile that honors the reservoir operating strategy. The water tank model is attached to an analytical aquifer model to capture the aquifer support effect. All the water produced from the reservoir, after discounting the cold water equivalent to the steam injected, is assumed to be aquifer water (Figure 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: APO MBAL Model

formatted-caption.caption-text: APO MBAL Model

linkTarget.anchoringText: then applying a non-linear regression on analytical aquifer parameters (Kv, Reservoir Radius, Water in place) to history match the pressure data collected from the Aquifer (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: History Matching - Analytical Method

formatted-caption.caption-text: History Matching - Analytical Method

linkTarget.anchoringText: The total water production profile from the latest business plan forecast was used in the first forecast iteration (yellow curve in Figure 11). The program then calculates the reservoir pressure drop. When the aquifer pressure reaches the 6000 kPa target, the total water rate (reservoir and aquifer combined) is then gradually reduced to maintain a constant aquifer pressure (red curve in Figure 11). The aquifer pump off rate (green curve in Figure 11) is then calculated for each step change.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: MBAL Results â€“ History Matching and Forecast

formatted-caption.caption-text: MBAL Results â€“ History Matching and Forecast

linkTarget.anchoringText: The 2015 history matched full field simulation model (FFM, see Figure 12 has been employed to verify the MBAL results, while accounting for reservoir heterogeneities, heat transfer and vertical conformance effects. The major risk evaluated by the FFM is a potential loss of oil into the aquifer as a result of higher reservoir operating pressure compared to the aquifer pressure. The production constraints in the full field model are based on latest Business Plan forecast.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: "A" West Full Field Model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: "A" West Full Field Model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The FFM was history matched up to 2014. The prediction runs constrained to 2015 and 2016 data were in line with observed pressure data. As captured in Figure 13 (magenta continuous line), the predicted pressure profile in April 2016 is consistent with the pressure profiles from MDT/XPT data collected in 2015 and 2016. The HM-FFM model suggests (Figure 13, green dashed line) that the aquifer pressure will reach 6000 kPa in 2019. This is aligned with the MBAL results.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: "A" West Full Field Model Results

formatted-caption.caption-text: "A" West Full Field Model Results

linkTarget.anchoringText: By looking at the results from a regional angle (Figure 14 and Figure 15), it has been observed that the planned pump-off rate in the Business Plan will reduce the "A" West Aquifer pressure to 6,000 kPa by 2023. Moreover, the model suggests that no more than 30% of the planned pump-off rate (~22,000 m3/d) after 2023 is needed to maintain the aquifer pressure at 6,000 kPa. It is worth underlining that these results are conservative, as the pressure looked at in this study is the average pressure of the whole "A" West aquifer rather than the pressure below the development area. The results from this study have been reflected in the high case forecast.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Regional Aquifer Study - The APO production rate, part of the total liquid production (blue line) increases to 87,600 m3. The steam injection rate (cyan line) increases to 18,000 t/d.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Regional Aquifer Study - The APO production rate, part of the total liquid production (blue line) increases to 87,600 m3. The steam injection rate (cyan line) increases to 18,000 t/d.

linkTarget.anchoringText: By looking at the results from a regional angle (Figure 14 and Figure 15), it has been observed that the planned pump-off rate in the Business Plan will reduce the "A" West Aquifer pressure to 6,000 kPa by 2023. Moreover, the model suggests that no more than 30% of the planned pump-off rate (~22,000 m3/d) after 2023 is needed to maintain the aquifer pressure at 6,000 kPa. It is worth underlining that these results are conservative, as the pressure looked at in this study is the average pressure of the whole "A" West aquifer rather than the pressure below the development area. The results from this study have been reflected in the high case forecast.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: "A" West reservoir pressure at 1050 m TVD ss resulting from different APO production rates from 0% (blue line), 20% (green), 40% (yellow), 60% (magenta), 70% (red), 80% (cyan), 90%.(grey) and 100% (green) of PB16 APO rates.

formatted-caption.caption-text: "A" West reservoir pressure at 1050 m TVD ss resulting from different APO production rates from 0% (blue line), 20% (green), 40% (yellow), 60% (magenta), 70% (red), 80% (cyan), 90%.(grey) and 100% (green) of PB16 APO rates.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the results from the above study, 7 wells were drilled from the Jadail water disposal site into the shallow Dammam Formation and connected to "A" West APO tank via an 18" GRE pipeline (Figure 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: "A" West APO Water Disposal System.

formatted-caption.caption-text: "A" West APO Water Disposal System.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The regional model covers the large fields "K" West, "N" and "A" West. Smaller fields included in the model are "I", "H" and "W" fields. Figure 17 captures the historical gross production profiles until 2015. Figure 17 also demonstrates that in the simulation models the historical gross production rates can be reproduced for all fields. The sharp increase of the gross production of "A" West in the year 2013 is a result of the start-up of the APO wells. Figure 18 shows that 95% of the total regional net liquid production is from the "N" (35%), "A" West (including APO 29%) and "K" West (31%) fields, where net production is defined as total liquid production minus total injection per field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: The historical and simulated regional liquid production rates

formatted-caption.caption-text: The historical and simulated regional liquid production rates

linkTarget.anchoringText: The regional model covers the large fields "K" West, "N" and "A" West. Smaller fields included in the model are "I", "H" and "W" fields. Figure 17 captures the historical gross production profiles until 2015. Figure 17 also demonstrates that in the simulation models the historical gross production rates can be reproduced for all fields. The sharp increase of the gross production of "A" West in the year 2013 is a result of the start-up of the APO wells. Figure 18 shows that 95% of the total regional net liquid production is from the "N" (35%), "A" West (including APO 29%) and "K" West (31%) fields, where net production is defined as total liquid production minus total injection per field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Regional historical net production per field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Regional historical net production per field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For each field a number of RFT pressure profiles have been selected. The RFT pressures at 1050 m TVD ss, all below the OWC, are subsequently plotted against time for the "K" West, "A" West, "N" and "L" fields; see the brown squares in Figure 19.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: The measured (brown) and simulated (yellow) pressure trends for "K" West (upper left), "N" (upper right), "A" West (lower left) and "L" (lower right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: The measured (brown) and simulated (yellow) pressure trends for "K" West (upper left), "N" (upper right), "A" West (lower left) and "L" (lower right).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The main uncertainties impacting the pressure history match and the forecast are the horizontal permeability of each of the four formations, the vertical permeability, the aquifer strength of the analytical aquifer, the fault transmissibility for all faults and the volume multiplier of each of the four formations. To investigate the impact of all these parameters on the history match and forecasts, a Design of Experiments workflow was applied. "N" and "A" reservoir pressure at 1050 m TVDss for all history matches are captured in Figure 20.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: "N" and "A" reservoir pressure at 1050 m TVD ss (history match and forecast) for all history matches.

formatted-caption.caption-text: "N" and "A" reservoir pressure at 1050 m TVD ss (history match and forecast) for all history matches.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To investigate the impact of "N" injection on the "A" reservoir pressure, the scenario of no "N" injection has been simulated, see the blue lines in Figure 21. This scenario is compared to the base case scenario (red line in Figure 21), whereby injection occurs in "N" and aquifer and production from the "A" aquifer. Up to 2023 we hardly observe a difference for the "A" pressures. After 2023 a difference of up to 5 bar can be seen. From this model it can be concluded that "N" injection has a negligible impact on the "A" aquifer pressure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Impact of "N" field injection on "A" reservoir pressure.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Impact of "N" field injection on "A" reservoir pressure.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To investigate the impact of "A" APO production on the "N" reservoir pressure, the scenario of no "A" production after 2016 has been simulated; see the green lines in Figure 22. In this scenario the "N" reservoir pressure increased by 2 bar in 2020 and 11 bar in 2040 compared to the base case forecast (red). From this figure it can be concluded that there is a limited impact from "A" APO on the "N" aquifer pressure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Impact of "A" production on "N" reservoir pressure: no "A" APO after 2016.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Impact of "A" production on "N" reservoir pressure: no "A" APO after 2016.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The resulting APO production profiles from three different studies are illustrated in Figure 23 below. The dot on each plot represents the year the Aquifer pressure reaches 6000 kPa. The primary constraint for the regional aquifer model is the production rate (from latest Business Plan). All the other models are pressure constrained (secondary constraint for MBAL) and hence observe a decline in APO production whenever the aquifer pressure reaches 6000 kPa. Based on the results from the multiple studies, three cases have been populated for the key assumptions of the predicted production profile (Table 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: APO production profiles resulting from the three studies together with the production forecast cases

formatted-caption.caption-text: APO production profiles resulting from the three studies together with the production forecast cases
